According to one informant, landless workers tended to stay put in the 19th century, but movement was possible and the relationship seems to have been a paternalistic one far from serfdom. In the 20th century landless workers have moved freely.

Differences is social status are in general slight, based on economic stability or membership in a chiefly family. There is one group that stands a little apart, the seyyids or half-seyyids--descendants of Muhammed. They live like anyone else, but derive prestige both from their genealogies and from their responsibility of conforming to the Hazara ideal of ethical behavior. For this reason they, like priests, were often called on to arrange a truce between warring factions or otherwise act as intermediaries in situations where the integrity of the agent was essential.
Prosperous families need workers to help in tilling the fields and herding livestock. These need not be permanent.
Although prosperous families are more likely to be able to hire itinerant Indian musicians for weddings, all members of the community would enjoy the music.

There was a more or less permanent organization of subtribes of various levels--a few tribes had tribal chiefs in the 19th century. Chiefs at the various levels could collect revenue, had some judicial functions, and acted as leaders in time of war or in dealing with outsiders. There was little centralized control, however, and the authority of a chief depended largely on his personality and his ability to contribute to the welfare of the group.
But such decisions were effective only if they met with the approval of the elders.

(-); Since the Hazaras celebrated Nau Ruz (New Year) and several Muslim festivals, one would infer that some individuals--probably the priests--made the astronomical observations necessary to fix the dates of these festivals.
